Award.AbstractNarration:
Large surveys of quasars are underway, such as SDSS-3 BOSS, that will provide a large set of quasar spectra. Even one such quasar spectrum contains an array of information, such as the Lyman-alpha forest that offers a map of the cosmological density field and provides hundreds of pixels of independent information. The project presents a coherent program that will build up a picture of the state of the intergalactic medium at high redshifts and its relationship and probe of cosmology. Large cosmological hydrodynamic simulations will be used to make predictions for observational measurements and to devise and test analysis techniques to be applied to data. Five aspects of the intergalactic matter field will be covered: the neutral medium, the ionized hydrogen field, the mass density field, the radiation field, and the temperature field.

This project will provide insight into the physics of the intergalactic medium, with its relationship to star and galaxy formation, as well as cosmology. The proposed work is not possible with smaller data sets and represents something new, and the potential future continuation with data from even larger surveys is clear. In addition, the sheer size of the data set will have a broad impact on the way spectroscopy is viewed, moving the study and mapping of the intergalactic medium into the realm of large-scale data mining. This work will push the development of software tools there were not previously necessary when analysis of quasar spectra involved only a small number of objects

Educationally, this project will assist the education of undergraduate and graduate students, and the results will be incorporated into an ongoing outreach program working with middle school students from minorities underrepresented in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit.

Over the last decade, the number of quasars with observed spectra has increased by a factor of nearly one thousand. Each spectrum carries with it spatial information about the hydrogen content of the Universe along the line of sight, in the so-called Lyman-alpha "forest" of absorption features. In our project we have shown how to put all these spectra together, turning hundreds of thousands of one dimensional skewers through the Universe into gigapixel three-dimensional maps. This mapping of the Universe has enabled the structure of matter, galaxies and dark matter to be probed in a qualitatively new way, and enabled different types of cosmological studies. Here are some examples from the course of the study:

The density of quasar sightlines has enabled precise statistical measures of spatial clustering to be computed from the Lyman-alpha forest. These include measurements of the Baryon Acoustic Oscillation (BAO) scale, which is governed by the speed of sound in the early Universe. The size of BAO can be calculated using known laboratory physics, so that when we measure it astronomically we can use it as a "standard ruler". The forest data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) were used to measure this scale at a previously unaccessible epoch, showing that the Universe was decelerating early in it's history, something which had been expected theoretically but never before observed directly.

We developed several techniques for reconstructing the full three-dimensional nature of structure in the Universe from the Lyman-alpha data. These included non-parametric methods, statistical techniques which don't require information from an underlying theoretical model. These were applied to data from hydrodynamic simulations as well as data from the SDSS (see Figure "A slice through the SDSS/BOSS Universe". The morphology of structure was strikingly revealed by maps we made using even higher resolution data, from a survey of the Lyman-alpha forest in a small patch of sky. An image of these maps, at a resolution of only about million light years (small scales for a cosmologist!) are shown in the Figure "Megaparsec resolution structure from the Lyman-alpha forest".

The extent of structure seen in the Lyman-alpha forest can also be used to put direct constraints on the constituents of the standard cosmological model. This model contains dark matter, but it's properties are only loosely known. One popular variant of dark matter, decaying dark matter (DDM) consists of a particle which decays to another (a "daughter"), with energy being released in the form of a kick velocity to the daughter particle.  The decay lifetime and the velocity kick are two parameters which we have strongly constrained by looking at how they affect structure in the Lyman-alpha forest (see Figure "Limits on the properties of decaying dark matter particles").

We have studied in the detail the interaction of sources of radiation, stars and black holes with the intergalactic medium probed by the  Lyman-alpha forest. We have developed techniques to model the heating and  the reionization of the gas using numerical simulations. One effect which  we have investigated is the inclusion of the evolution of the universe in "mock observations" of the simulation. This is known as the "light-cone" effect  and how it changes the appearance of structure is illustrated in the  figure "A simulation showing the evolution of the Universe".
